title: Author Jessica Fellowes (niece of Julian Fellowes) reveals she was let go for 'sounding too posh'
text:
Esteemed author Jessica Fellowes has revealed she was fired from her old job for sounding 'too posh'.

The niece of Downton Abbey screenwriter and Conservative Julian Fellowes, said she was sent packing from her position as assistant editor of a contract magazine for sounding like 'she was born with a silver spoon in her mouth'.

'You'd never catch an employer criticising someone for sounding as though they'd been brought up on a council estate,' she told The Telegraph.

Now living in Oxfordshire with her family and a labradoodle, Jessica has since written five glamorous books to the Highclere Castle-based programme, alongside several novels focusing on the aristocratic Mitford family.

Esteemed author Jessica Fellows, pictured speaking at Cliveden House, Berkshire, at an event hosted by the Women's Chapter and Rolls Royce, has revealed she was fired from her job as assistant editor at a contract magazine for sounding 'too posh'

Jessica, pictured at the East Riding Festival of Words and who has written several books on Downton Abbey, was told she 'sounded like she was born with a silver spoon in her mouth'

She revealed that when her boss at the unnamed publication asked why she was being fired, the reply was: 'There's nothing really wrong with the way Jessica works, but she was born with a silver spoon in her mouth.'

She added: 'Which made me laugh (though not all the way to the bank: I had to find another job) at how such inverted snobbery had been deemed acceptable.

Defiantly, Jessica refused to change her accent, saying it would be too 'cringe' to change her voice.

She is the niece of Conservative peer to the House of Lords and Downton Abbey screenwriter Julian Fellowes, far right, pictured with actors (from left to right) Hugh Bonneville, Elizabeth McGovern, Michelle Dockery, Laura Carmichael and Allen Leech at the London premiere of Downton Abbey last month

He was educated at Magdalene College, Oxford, and was born in Cairo, Egypt, while his father worked in the British Embassy in the country. Fellowes is pictured with Duchess of York Sarah Ferguson, and at a Downton Abbey screening in Washington at the British Ambassador's residence

Perhaps surprisingly, many Brits still believe that a strong regional accent can act as a barrier in their careers.

And a University of Manchester and University of Bath study published earlier this year concluded that strongly localised voice could 'harm social mobility' as it makes them 'less favoured' by employers.

One teacher that took part in the research claimed her working-class South London accent signalled she was authentic and, as a result, more approachable for students.

However, her mentor claimed that they thought it made her sound 'unprofessional'.

According to Jessica's LinkedIn profile, she started off as Assistant Editor at trade magazine Marketing Business, where she worked for ten months before becoming a feature writer for the Mail on Sunday.

Her uncle Julian Fellowes was the screenwriter for the Downton Abbey series and the movie

Downton Abbey follows the lives of the aristocratic family that live at the house, and the many servants they employ

She then became the Deputy Editor of Country Life, famous for writing about glamorous houses and the royals, and became a columnist on the now defunct The London Paper.

In 2008 she became an author after her first book Mud and the City: Dos and Don'ts for Townies in the Country was published.

Research carried out by the University of Manchester and the University of Bath in February
description: Author Jessica Fellowes from Oxfordshire was fired by a magazine for being 'too posh', and said that you wouldn't get the same 'reverse snobbery' towards someone from a council house.
